Quantum theory is a branch of mathematics, and like all branches of mathematics, it has its own foundations. The foundations of quantum theory are the subject of a lively debate. The most common approach is to use the language of analysis, and to assume that the objects of quantum theory, such as states and observables, are continuous functions from a suitable space of states or observables to a suitable space of complex numbers. We provide a different approach, based on category theory, which does not assume that the objects of quantum theory are continuous. We show that the category of quantum states is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functionals on a suitable space of operators. This approach has the advantage that it is purely categorical, and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoans and the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the evolution of the myxozoan body plan and the origin of the Myxozoa. (Read more)

COVID-19 is a disease that has caused a global pandemic. The virus that causes this disease, SARS-CoV-2, is able to block the action of the IFN pathway, which is a major antiviral pathway. This study shows that the virus uses a protein that is part of its structure to block the action of the IFN pathway.

Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. The world will need to produce more food in the coming decades to feed a projected 10 billion people. This will be challenging because of the effects of climate change, including rising temperatures. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and yield variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is one of the most important problems in ecology. In the case of large mammalian herbivores, the coexistence of species is facilitated by niche partitioning, the use of different resources by different species. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the degree to which different species partition food resources, and that this approach can be used to identify the degree to which different species partition food resources. Our results suggest that the coexistence of species in savanna ecosystems is more tightly linked to plant diversity than previously thought. This work has implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that facilitate the coexistence of species in other ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely across businesses, and many businesses expect to remain open for at least several months. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks, which remove millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

The age of the solar system is one of the most important and fundamental facts in astronomy. It is also one of the most difficult to determine. We determined the age of the solar system by measuring the exposure age of presolar silicon carbide grains in the Murchison CM2 meteorite.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.
The ability to reproduce is the most important trait for the survival of a species. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most variable trait in nature.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. Here we report the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA, in which we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in the striatum of the mouse model. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an important step toward the development of a therapeutic agent for MSA. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is able to control these functions by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that is highly efficient in terms of both local and global communication. This organization is effective in controlling the functions of the endothelium and in maintaining the stability of the network. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders, including public health practitioners, epidemiologists, researchers, and policymakers. We encourage the community to use and build upon the API. We also encourage the community to contribute to the development of the API by submitting new data sources and signals. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be a valuable resource for the COVID-19 response and beyond.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled, and an allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter on activation. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. These results provide a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. They also provide a molecular explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in the absence of activation gating. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diseases associated with potassium channels. View Full-Text

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health and disease of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood, and there is a need for the development of new therapeutics to treat diseases caused by dysbiosis of the microbiome. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward processing. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in the development of social hierarchy. View Full-Text

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of aging. This study demonstrates that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is involved in the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression. This study also demonstrates that IGF2BP1 is a potential target of aging. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of aging-associated hemoglobin disorders.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the survival rate of patients with cancer remains low. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis in cancer cells, which is mediated by the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis and the subsequent up-regulation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. This mechanism can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, and the combination of ferroptosis induction and mTORC1 inhibition can be used to treat cancer. These findings provide a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, the most common type of heart disease. Hypertension is also the most common risk factor for heart failure. Hypertension is also the leading cause of death worldwide. Hypertension is a major cause of heart failure, and heart failure is the leading cause of death worldwide. Therefore, the development of drugs that can treat hypertension is of great importance. We identified a mechanism of action of a class of drugs that are used to treat hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and provided a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results provide a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

We introduce a new deep learning architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many applications of deep learning. We hope that the proposed architecture will be useful to the deep learning community.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The results provide a unique insight into the influence of climate on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin secretion, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness and performance of the reader. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary marks a major cooling of the climate, and it is hypothesized that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources, and that the Os in the YDB is not derived from an extraterrestrial source. The YDB is therefore not a YDB, but a YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is more complex than previously thought.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits are transmitted from one generation to the next, and the result of which is the evolution of technology. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and culture, and for the design of social systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. This article is protected by copyright

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the innermost part of the Earth. It is a key part of the Earth's interior, but its formation mechanism is still unknown. The required degree of undercooling for the formation of the inner core is a key factor in solving the paradox. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the bcc phase of iron is the first nucleus, followed by the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well documented, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to show that the most powerful deep learning models for natural language processing also outperform all other models on a task of fundamental importance for language processing: predicting the next word in a sentence. This result provides computational evidence that the predictive processing that is a hallmark of deep learning is also a hallmark of language processing in the human brain. These results have implications for understanding the nature of language and the human brain. They also have implications for the design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been successful in many applications, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that DL methods are often unstable, even when universal approximation properties guarantee the existence of stable neural networks (NNs). We show that this paradox is due to the fact that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable NNs, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results provide a classification theory of conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of DL. They also provide a theoretical explanation for the failure of DL in some problems. They are thus of interest to both the machine learning and scientific computing communities.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a case study in the failure of science communication. The study of exponential growth, which is the basis of the pandemic’s exponential spread, is a classic example of a phenomenon that is difficult to understand for the general public. This study, published in 1972, has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 years. However, it is based on a flawed design, which was not recognized at the time and is only now being discussed.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the chronic, diffuse form of leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient from Mexico, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation, and that the two species are closely related. This suggests that the two species are still capable of causing disease in humans. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of leprosy, which is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. This survey shows that the two species are still found in the same regions of the world. This is important because it suggests that the two species are still capable of causing disease in humans. The dynamics of entanglement and entropy is a central issue in quantum physics. It is also a very difficult one, because it is usually studied in the limit of infinite system size, which is not accessible in practice. Here, we show that a careful analysis of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit leads to a complete understanding of the dynamics in the whole parameter space. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we discuss its implications for the dynamics of entanglement in general isolated systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 500,000 deaths in the United States alone. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a vaccine that is easy to manufacture, requires only one dose, and is effective in preventing COVID-19. This vaccine could be used to vaccinate the entire population, thus helping to end the pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, this study shows that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, could have been the primary vector of the disease. This has important implications for the control of the disease, as it would have been easier to control if the vector was human rather than rodent. Our results also suggest that the Black Death was not a single epidemic, but rather a series of epidemics, which could have had a significant impact on the history of Europe. This study has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the history of human population dynamics in Europe.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain size is not always a good proxy for the evolution of brain power. This study shows that the evolution of the amniote brain is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons, which are associated with the evolution of intelligence. These results have important implications for the study of the evolution of brain size and cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is unknown. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF-induced curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on binding and weakly enhances severing. Furthermore, we find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We propose that this ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing, which is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF in severing actin filaments. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that are involved in severing filaments. This framework may be useful in understanding the role of these proteins in a variety of biological processes.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a popular sweetener because it is sweeter than glucose. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and brain reward processing have not been well studied. In this study, we show that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and the development of obesity. Future studies should examine the effects of fructose on body weight and the role of fructose in the development of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We present a detailed picture of the genetic history of the Malagasy people, which is a unique case in the world. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The genetic structure of the Malagasy people is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure. These results provide a detailed picture of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world. They also provide a reference for the genetic history of the Indian Ocean region. We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences that person’s own emotional state. This work suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on mRNA structure and function. In this study, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the products of translation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. They also highlight the importance of considering the effects of mRNA modifications on the translation of mRNA in the context of the cell. (Read more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important and most studied topics in biology. This study shows that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the major cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause severe infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as patients with cystic fibrosis. The bacterium is able to adapt to different environments and is able to cause infections in different organs, such as the lungs, the urinary tract, and the bloodstream. The mechanisms that the bacterium uses to adapt to different environments and to cause infections are not completely understood. Here we show that the bacterium uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and this has led to increasing contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global extent of pesticide contamination of surface waters, the risk of exceeding regulatory threshold levels, and the dependence on the type of insecticide, the time since its introduction, and the stringency of environmental regulations. The results suggest that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to a wide variety of animal species, including deer, and may persist in the animal population. Here, we describe the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, and the rapid spread of the virus in deer populations during the winter months. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and tau tangles, but the earliest stages of the disease are poorly understood. Here, we identify the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies. They also provide a basis for further studies to understand the role of the Aβ-burdened neuron in the AD pathogenesis. This study may lead to the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The use of chickens for economic purposes is one of the most important developments in the history of agriculture. The earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens comes from the ancient Near East, where the use of chickens is documented in the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We present evidence that the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct pathways are involved. This study shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, involves at least two distinct native-like intermediates in distinct folding pathways. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is not a single process but a series of processes. The results also suggest that the folding of a protein is not a single process but a series of processes.

We describe a mechanism for the decapping of dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are known to accumulate in cells under conditions of stress. This work provides a glimpse into the mechanisms by which bacteria adapt to stress, and it may have implications for the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial infection.

Sepsis is a major health problem, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is needed. We have demonstrated that arginine, a major amino acid, is essential for the survival of T lymphocytes and that citrulline, the metabolic product of arginine, is a promising alternative to arginine in the treatment of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass of different taxa. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit with a continuous time evolution. This is in contrast to all known models of SOC, which are discrete. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in the semiconductor industry. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks. Therefore, it is desirable to control its mechanical properties, such as its strength and ductility. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or demetallized, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to control the mechanical properties of diamond, and to use it in new applications.

This study describes the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula. The peptide was shown to bind to multiple phosphoinositides in vitro, and to cause cell death in germlings of plant fungal pathogens. The peptide was shown to be effective in controlling gray mold disease in plants. This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this class of peptides, and opens up the possibility of using them as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work may also provide a structural framework for the design of antifungal peptides with improved activity and specificity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the contributions of males and females are intertwined. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work may also have implications for the study of other species, including humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the binding of platelets to the vessel wall. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF is able to switch between two states, one of which is more sensitive to flow. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD and may be important in other diseases in which the flow sensitivity of VWF is altered. The results provide a mechanism for the effects of flow on the function of VWF. The results also provide a mechanism for the effects of flow on the function of VWF.

The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that has been shown to influence human health and disease. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on the human body, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses associated with the human body, which will be useful for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The results of this study will help to improve the representation of ACI in climate models. This will, in turn, help to improve our understanding of the climate system. Thus, this study will have a significant impact on the climate science.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts, which, however, have been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their conductance and activation/deactivation kinetics. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel that is normally open and inactivated by slow C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. It also provides a new target for the development of drugs and gene therapy. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, which can be used for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum physics.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of low humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and may contribute to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza in low humidity conditions. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole, from the top down, by merging words into phrases. Here, we show that the brain is already building a phrase structure as it processes each word in a sentence. This is the first time that this has been demonstrated in the human brain.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway. It is a scaffold that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. In vertebrates, there are two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of redundant genes and their regulation. It also provides a resource for future studies on the regulation of redundant genes. This study is of interest to researchers in the fields of cell signaling, genetics, and molecular biology.

This study provides a detailed characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity. The lateral hypothalamus is a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of this region induces eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is involved in the development of obesity, as lesions of this circuit in mice lead to an increase in body weight.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the major factor limiting plant growth. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and to direct them to a desired host plant, would therefore be a major advance in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and that directs them to a desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We report the discovery of a new form of hearing in the orb-weaving spider, Larinioides sclopetarius. The spider’s hearing is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is used to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider’s outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing hearing in animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also demonstrate that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health. The development of vaccines is a major step forward in controlling the pandemic, but the cost of these vaccines is a major barrier to their global access. Here we report a strategy for the development of a subunit vaccine that is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is more easily manufactured and has enhanced immunogenicity compared to the currently approved vaccines. This strategy may be used to develop vaccines for other pathogens.
We describe the identification of a ligand for the ALK family of receptors in the zebrafish. This ligand is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in the history of infectious disease. The study of ancient plague genomes has provided a unique window into the origins of this devastating disease. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient plague genomes from across Eurasia, which reveals a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a valuable resource for future studies of plague’s origins and evolution. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. The findings suggest that the endorsement of HM is a powerful predictor of men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has a large impact on the global carbon cycle. In this study, we show that the management of croplands and grasslands can be used to increase the amount of carbon stored in the soil. This is important because the amount of carbon stored in the soil is a key factor in the fight against climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms underlying the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we describe a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin, that is responsible for the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of nectar color in plants and animals. (Read more)

We present a study of the genetic structure of the population in the late 5th/early 6th century AD in southern Germany. The analysis of the genetic data indicates that the genetic structure of the population in this period was very complex, with a high degree of heterogeneity in the genetic ancestry of the individuals. This heterogeneity is particularly striking in women, who show a very high degree of genetic diversity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The human genome is replicated in the nucleus by a complex of DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). This study provides a detailed analysis of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme, which is the active enzyme within the complex. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as previously thought and that the stability of the complex is dependent on the replication process. This study provides a better understanding of the replication process and the factors that contribute to the stability of the complex. It also provides a foundation for future studies of the stability of the complex in disease states.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases have been used to synthesize RNA molecules, but the ability to replicate nucleic acids, to amplify short templates, and to synthesize functional RNA molecules has been achieved only in the presence of proteins. Here, we describe a method for the in vitro evolution of RNA polymerases that can replicate nucleic acids, amplify templates, and synthesize functional RNA molecules. This method can be used to study the origin of life in the laboratory. It also provides a platform for the study of the origin of life in the universe.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that it will be useful to urban planners, geographers, and others interested in the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the mortality rate is high. The current treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19. It is expected that this study will provide a reference for the treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 in the future.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal, and the ability to control copper levels is important for the survival of fungi. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the binding and sequestration of copper. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that fungal natural products may be involved in the control of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This study also demonstrates the utility of the CAS assay in the study of fungal natural products. This assay can be used to screen for fungal natural products that bind copper, and may be useful in the study of other metal homeostasis mechanisms in fungi. (Read more)

The chemistry and mineralogy of the surface of Mars is important for understanding the history of the planet and its environment. The chemistry and mineralogy of the surface of Mars is also important for understanding the habitability of the surface environment. The chemistry and mineralogy of the surface of Mars is also important for understanding the origin of the surface material.

Frost is a major environmental stress for plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees in Europe and Asia. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of the development of Th1-like cells from Th17 precursors is unknown. Here we show that the development of Th1-like cells is required for the development of colitis, and that this process requires the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IL-17 receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease of motor neurons. There is a need for rapid, reproducible, and disease-relevant models to identify disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. Here, we report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid, high-throughput disease modeling and drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will be useful for ALS research and drug development. It will also be applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson’s disease and Huntington’s disease. The method is also applicable to other cell types, such as microglia, which are involved in neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using a host protein to alter the microbiota of its vector. This study also provides a model for understanding the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of modern avian form. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, which adds important information about the origin of the modern avian tail.

We show that the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature is a significant contributor to the climate sensitivity of the climate system. This is a new finding, and it has important implications for the design of climate experiments in climate models. It also has implications for the interpretation of observations of stratospheric water vapor. The increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature is a well-known feature of the climate system, but it has not been previously considered as a contributor to climate sensitivity. This work provides a new perspective on the role of water vapor in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is used for a variety of purposes, including communication, camouflage, and warning. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color change, which is based on the ability of a protein to absorb light in a specific wavelength range.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. It is difficult to treat because of the presence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the recurrence of the disease. We have identified a mechanism that may be used to target CSCs in breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skin for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method that can be used to determine the origin of the animal skin used to make parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skin for parchment is not necessary to produce the tissue-thin parchment needed for the production of pocket Bibles.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This work will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract. Although the etiology of IBD is not fully understood, it is believed to be associated with the immune system. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal inflammation. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the pathogenesis of IBD. View Full-Text

We have developed a method to study the conformational changes that occur in the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 as it binds to the human receptor, ACE2. We have used this method to study the conformational changes that occur in the spike protein as it binds to the human receptor, ACE2. We have found that the spike protein can adopt a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may not be the only factor that determines the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of changes in fire activity over the last century, and that this trend is likely to continue in the future. However, we also find that climate change has been the dominant driver of warming over the last century, and that this trend is likely to continue in the future. This means that climate change is the primary driver of warming, and that human ignitions and fire suppression are not the only drivers of warming. This has important implications for climate change mitigation and adaptation.

This study shows that the provision of a single glycan by the host to its symbiotic partner is sufficient to regulate the activity of the symbiont and the health of the mutualism. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is active and the symbiont is at its most productive. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the importance of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis dynamics. It also suggests that the provision of glycans may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbial communities in animals. This mechanism may be important for the health of the host and the symbiont, and may be conserved in other animal–microbe interactions.

We present a method for identifying latent topics in text data. We use a generative model to represent a sequence of words as a distribution over topics. We then use a discriminative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method can be used to identify topics in structured and unstructured text, and to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. View Full-Text

This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific coast of North America. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality in this group of animals. The study also provides evidence that the virus is widespread in the environment, suggesting that it has been present in the region for a long time.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic data, with a strong influence of geography on the distribution of African and Asian ancestry. These results provide a detailed picture of the history of Madagascar, and they have implications for the study of human migrations and the origin of the Malagasy language. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR).
