The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop condition monitoring is a key component of agricultural production management, and is essential for early detection of crop anomalies, which can be used to mitigate losses and improve yields. Current condition monitoring systems rely on satellite imagery, crop growth models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized the information provided by crop experts. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting information on crop status for decades, can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to improve agricultural management. Our approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor other agricultural products such as livestock, fisheries, and forestry.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, there is also evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation plays a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability that occur in neurons during learning. This mechanism is able to support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. It is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results add a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. We hope that this synthesis will be useful to the scientific community and the general public.

The evolutionary history of the plastid genome is a unique window into the history of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is visible in the plastid genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, and we show that the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is shaped by the macroevolutionary events that characterize the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. Our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of the plastid genome, and for the study of the evolution of life on Earth.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water availability. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of materials. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, provides a unique link between the two.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are the most important molecules in this process. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one from plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria, and the other from anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria. Here we show that the two enzymes are related, and that they are part of three classes based on their requirement for additional subunits. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Read more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme drought in the state in the past 1,200 y. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggest that the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a potential therapeutic target for autism. This study also provides a model system for understanding the role of forgetting in learning and memory. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is based on a 17-country, 6-continent study of the psychophysiological reactions of 1,000 people to real news video content. The results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

We report the identification of two mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and one mutation in the pore-forming protein of the store-operated Ca2+ (CRAC) channel that cause a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy, but without hematological abnormalities. We also report the identification of a second mutation in ORAI1, which causes a Stormorken syndrome of thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. We describe a model for the propagation of protein aggregates in the brain, which may be relevant to a number of neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTB4 generation and the antiviral immune response of the host. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of LTB4 in the immune response of bats and the potential of LTB4 as a therapeutic target for the control of viral infections in bats. These findings may contribute to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the control of viral infections in bats. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the most important metabolic changes in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. This one-carbon unit is used to synthesize purine and thymidine, which are essential for cell growth. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that these compounds block colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, one-carbon metabolism is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule cancer therapeutics that target one-carbon metabolism. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone, and the inclusion bodies that form in the motor neurons of patients are composed of a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics. Here, we show that the inclusion bodies are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the three proteins, but rather are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases caused by aggregation-prone proteins. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases caused by aggregation-prone proteins. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be broadly applicable to many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The Cretaceous is a key period in the history of life, and the study of the origin of the flowering plants is of great importance. The study of the aquatic flowering plants of the Cretaceous is of particular interest because of the possible role that aquatic habitats may have played in the early diversification of the flowering plants. The study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous aquatic flowering plant, is presented here, and its position in the angiosperm phylogeny is discussed.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This result is important because it provides a direct measurement of the rate of sea level rise that can be used to evaluate climate models and to assess the vulnerability of coastal communities to sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the rate and stereoselectivity of the reaction. The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is also a key determinant of the structure of the enzyme-substrate complex, which is the substrate for the next step in the reaction. Thus, the structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key determinant of the overall reaction pathway. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state for a reaction that is catalyzed by a family of enzymes, including tryptophan synthase, and to understand the reaction pathway. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe, often fatal, disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the available treatment options are limited. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in humans, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS in humans. It may also be effective against other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This warrants further investigation. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. (Read more)

This study shows that the provision of a single glycan by the host to its symbiotic partner is sufficient to regulate the activity of the symbiont and the health of the mutualism. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provisioned at a specific time of day, which is linked to the maturation of the symbiotic organ. This glycan is also required for the acidification of the symbiotic habitat, which is required for the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes, and may have implications for the health of the host.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce the use of suspension in schools. The study also shows that it is possible to change the way teachers think about discipline. This is a significant contribution to the field of education, and it has implications for the way we think about the role of teachers in society.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked the sequential proteolysis required for virus entry. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also be relevant to the pathogenesis of other viruses that require sequential proteolysis for infection. (Read more)

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the environment, and it is therefore important to understand how to change people’s food choices to reduce environmental impacts. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% in a large-scale field study. This is a large effect, and it is likely that the proportion of vegetarian meals could be increased further without rebound effects. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a major impact on the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to the general scientific community, as well as to the public, because it provides a systems-level view of the cell surface in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide evidence from the staggered implementation of universal vote-by-mail in three US states. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein at 2.04-Å resolution. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and/or immune suppression. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. We live in an era of big data. This is a good thing, because it allows us to study many more phenomena than in the past. However, big data also creates new challenges, because it is difficult to know how to assess the significance of the results. We describe a new approach to selective inference, which allows us to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This approach can be used in many areas of study, including forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks, which may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the formation of ETVECs in vitro and the improvement of blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using ETVECs in mice indicate that ETVECs may be a useful tool for the study of human EC development and the treatment of vascular disorders. These findings also provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

We describe the discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and Ltk. We show that these ligands play an important role in the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. We also demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. Finally, we show that these ligands are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a better understanding of the function of RTKs and their ligands in the development of the eye and the skin. It also provides a model system for the study of the role of RTKs and their ligands in the development of the eye and the skin. This work may also have implications for the study of cancer.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular basis of T2D is still unclear, insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated. Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING deficiency in high-fat diet–fed mice alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance, it surprisingly impaired insulin secretion from β-cells. Importantly, STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is advantageous for the virus, but it also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This mechanism is sequence dependent and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation of this mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. They also provide a molecular basis for the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to the loss of forest and rangeland ecosystems. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of the neighborhoods. These correlations are consistent with three classical theories of urban change: human capital, tipping, and invasion. Our results provide support for these theories and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. We hope that our work will inspire more research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in insects remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. View Full-Text

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to microcephaly and other neurological disorders. The current outbreak has led to a global concern for the safety of pregnant women. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual animals. We estimate that the time between infection and the onset of symptoms is ∼10 d, the time between cell infection and viral production is most likely short (∼4 h), the within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC5

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs. The underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome and stimulate tumor growth. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and for the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide a model system for studying the role of the microbiome in intestinal homeostasis and regeneration. This model could be used to study the role of the microbiome in the development of other diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease. Finally, our findings could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients relapse. Chemotherapy may also select for cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which also enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs.

The timing of the onset of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most important questions in the history of the Earth system. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption in the Southern Alps of New Zealand, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the westerlies.

Freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries and to protect biodiversity, and to better target conservation efforts to protect the most productive rivers.

Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as the next generation of energy storage devices due to their inherent safety. However, the development of high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries is still challenging due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material exhibits a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with the material. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a hallmark of the mammalian nervous system. However, in the adult mammalian CNS, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the ability to regenerate may be more widespread than previously appreciated.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the evolution of new traits. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we identify some striking similarities and differences with recombination in other eukaryotes.

The resting brain is organized in networks, which are thought to be involved in the control of cognitive and emotional functions. The present study provides a detailed description of the resting brain organization in health and disease, using a novel approach that combines resting metabolic imaging with network analysis. The results provide a detailed description of the resting brain organization in health and disease, and suggest that the resting brain can be viewed as a network of networks. The results also suggest that the resting brain is not a homogeneous system, but rather a complex network of networks, which can be described in terms of a hierarchy of dominant and subordinate networks.

This study describes a new type of RNA modification in eukaryotes, the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. This modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is produced cotranscriptionally. The 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.
This study provides a better understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the drug sensitivity of TNBC cells. Our findings may aid in the design of therapies for TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the volatile chemicals produced during ripening. These chemicals are produced by a variety of metabolic pathways, including the biosynthesis of nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known in tomato, and the contribution of these pathways to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe when species diversity is low or high, rather than moderate. This is because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is driven by the thermal tolerance of species, and the impacts of warming on the thermal tolerance of species are more severe when diversity is low or high. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of global warming on the thermal tolerance of species in the context of biodiversity loss.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key region of the hippocampus involved in navigation. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled, while border, HD, and OV cells tend to intermingle. These data suggest that grid cells may be largely distinct from those of other cell types. Our results also suggest that the grid cell network is more complex than previously thought. They provide a detailed view of the activity of neurons in MEC and parasubiculum, which will be useful for understanding the organization of these regions and their function in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by many genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal in plants is not only controlled by the flowering genes in the plant itself, but also by the flowering genes in other plants. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and the evolution of flowering regulation.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain. It is caused by degeneration of the neurons that produce dopamine in the midbrain, the nigral cells. We have found that these neurons are connected to the striatum, the brain region that is the primary target of the nigral system, by a system of fibers that originate in the striosomes of the nigral cells. The striosomes are specialized regions of the dopamine neurons that are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We propose that the striosome–striatonigral fibers that originate in the striosomes form specialized integrative units within the dopamine system, and that they could be critical to the function of the system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We often use the word "click" to describe the feeling of connection, but how do we know when two people are "clicking"? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to gauge the quality of their connection with others, and it is used by others to gauge the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cells, the sinoatrial cells (SANCs), which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized organ that is able to adjust its rate to meet the changing demands of the body. This is achieved by a complex interplay between the membrane and the store-operated Ca2+ entry systems. We show that the store-operated Ca2+ entry system is a key regulator of the electrical activity of SANCs and that it is responsible for the maintenance of the SAN rate. These studies reveal a previously unrecognized role for the store-operated Ca2+ entry system in the regulation of the electrical activity of the heart. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the environment, and its beneficial effects on plant growth and development have been well documented. However, the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a sustainable strategy for enhancing plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study also provides a model for understanding the interaction between Si and JA in plant defense. (Read more)

This study demonstrates the importance of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. The results also reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of this integration that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and fiber for the human population. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, which is a major advance in the field of plant biology. We also show that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology community and will help in the development of plant biotechnology.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is often overlooked in efforts to reduce coastal eutrophication. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients. This is important because dissolved inorganic nutrients are more bioavailable to algae, which can lead to more frequent and intense algal blooms. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal eutrophication, and that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in large water bodies should include small tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a rare combination of forces. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of the origin of fine-tuning in nature.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It is a significant contribution to the field of neuroimmunology and will be of interest to a broad audience of scientists and clinicians.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a global warming, anoxia of the deep ocean, and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. These changes were linked to the injection of organic matter into the ocean, which led to a global increase in the amount of C in the system. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that led to the evolution of the Earth system and the origin of life. They also provide a framework for understanding the history of abrupt climate change in the past and the potential for such changes in the future.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification has a positive impact on the rate of deforestation, but that this impact is largely due to the certification of plantations that are already small and contain little residual forest. We also show that certification has no impact on the rate of active fire detection in oil palm plantations. Our results suggest that certification has not yet achieved its full potential to reduce deforestation, and that the scheme will need to be strengthened to achieve this goal.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins, lipids, and other molecules from the endosome to the cytoplasm. The exocyst complex is involved in the final step of this process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and also offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a key evolutionary process that has shaped the evolution of vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination loci, however, sex determination is polygenic. Here we show that polygenic sex determination can produce a modular response in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive species that are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and by light. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of adducts of vitamin A that are generated by light and by reactive species. The retina is a model for the study of the effects of iron on redox and the generation of reactive species.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the functioning of food webs. In this study, we show that the evolution of the feeding strategies of siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians, is linked to the evolution of their tentacles. Our results suggest that the evolution of the feeding strategies of predators is linked to the evolution of their morphology, and that the evolution of morphology is linked to the evolution of feeding strategies. These findings contribute to understanding the evolution of the feeding strategies of predators, and the functioning of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that it arose in the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the most important metabolic changes in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. This one-carbon unit is used to synthesize purine and thymidine, which are essential for cell growth. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that these compounds block colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, one-carbon metabolism is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule cancer therapeutics that target one-carbon metabolism. (Read more)

This study shows that deforestation has a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results of this study have implications for policy makers, as well as for researchers and practitioners working in the fields of nutrition, environment, and development.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show here that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
